National Science Foundation halts reviews of research proposals The National Science Foundation has halted for at least the rest of the week the work of review panels, in which outside experts rate the merit of proposals for scientific research. The NSF, a $10 billion agency that spreads research dollars across the country in quantities both large and small, issued a brief statement Monday that added minimal clarity to a situation that had alarmed researchers. “All review panels scheduled for the remainder of this week, 1/28-1/31 will be rescheduled to a future date as appropriate,” an NSF spokesperson said in an email. “This will allow the agency to make the best use of everyone’s time and resources as we continue to develop guidance to ensure compliance with the recent executive orders.” The broader scientific community has been scrambling for the past week amid a flurry of executive orders from President Donald Trump, including his directive to end all diversity, equity and inclusion programs. Federal science agencies, including NSF, NASA and the National Institutes of Health, have broadly embraced the need to diversify the community of researchers and the subjects they study. The cancellations at NSF come in the wake of news that NIH had also paused the work of study sections that review grants.
